page.title: 08WOODLANDS, CLIFTON HAMPDEN
page.content: A large part of the land in the north eastern part of this area is covered by woodlands. The woodlands, which are part of the Nuneham Park estate,are managed as such. Originally these were primarily mixed plantings of oak, ash, cherry and chestnut. Modern replanting is of conifer and hardwood in a ratio of about 2:1. Clifton Heath used to be mostly oak woodland, but much of this was felled during World War II, and it is now mainly birch with a little oak and cherry. Woodland edge plants such as bluebells, primroses and red campion abound in the newer plantations. Broad leaved helleborines and honeysuckle may also be found and, in the autumn, various types of fungi, including mushrooms, can be seen along the verges of the woods.
